The Trade-off between Processing Gains of an Impulse Radio UWB System in the Presence of Timing Jitter11{}^{\textrm{\small{1}}}

Sinan Gezici2, Member, IEEE, Andreas F. Molisch3, Fellow, IEEE,
H. Vincent Poor4, Fellow, IEEE, and Hisashi Kobayashi4, Life Fellow, IEEE
Abstract

In time hopping impulse radio, NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f} pulses of duration TcsubscriptùëáùëêT_{c} are transmitted for each information symbol. This gives rise to two types of processing gain: (i) pulse combining gain, which is a factor NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}, and (ii) pulse spreading gain, which is Nc=Tf/TcsubscriptùëÅùëêsubscriptùëáùëìsubscriptùëáùëêN_{c}=T_{f}/T_{c}, where TfsubscriptùëáùëìT_{f} is the mean interval between two subsequent pulses. This paper investigates the trade-off between these two types of processing gain in the presence of timing jitter. First, an additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel is considered and approximate closed form expressions for bit error probability are derived for impulse radio systems with and without pulse-based polarity randomization. Both symbol-synchronous and chip-synchronous scenarios are considered. The effects of multiple-access interference and timing jitter on the selection of optimal system parameters are explained through theoretical analysis. Finally, a multipath scenario is considered and the trade-off between processing gains of a synchronous impulse radio system with pulse-based polarity randomization is analyzed. The effects of the timing jitter, multiple-access interference and inter-frame interference are investigated. Simulation studies support the theoretical results.

Index Terms‚Äî‚ÄÜImpulse radio ultra-wideband (IR-UWB), timing jitter, multiple-access interference (MAI), inter-frame interference (IFI), Rake receiver.

I Introduction

Recently, communication systems that employ ultra-wideband (UWB) signals have drawn considerable attention. UWB systems occupy a bandwidth larger than 500 MHz, and they can coexist with incumbent systems in the same frequency range due to large spreading factors and low power spectral densities. Recent Federal Communications Commission (FCC) rulings [1], [2] specify the regulations for UWB systems in the US.

Commonly, impulse radio (IR) systems, which transmit very short pulses with a low duty cycle, are employed to implement UWB systems [3]-[5]. Although the short duration of UWB pulses is advantageous for precise positioning applications [6], it also presents practical difficulties such as synchronization, which requires efficient search strategies [7]. In an IR system, a train of pulses is sent and information is usually conveyed by the positions or the amplitudes of the pulses, which correspond to pulse position modulation (PPM) and pulse amplitude modulation (PAM), respectively. Also, in order to prevent catastrophic collisions among different users and thus provide robustness against multiple access interference, each information symbol is represented not by one pulse but by a sequence of pulses and the locations of the pulses within the sequence are determined by a pseudo-random time-hopping (TH) sequence [3].

The number of pulses that are sent for each information symbol is denoted by NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}. This first type of processing gain is called the pulse combining gain. The second type of processing gain NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} is the pulse spreading gain, and is defined as the ratio of average time between the two consecutive transmissions (TfsubscriptùëáùëìT_{f}) and the actual transmission time (TcsubscriptùëáùëêT_{c}); that is, Nc=Tf/TcsubscriptùëÅùëêsubscriptùëáùëìsubscriptùëáùëêN_{c}=T_{f}/T_{c}. The total processing gain is defined as N=Nc‚ÄãNfùëÅsubscriptùëÅùëêsubscriptùëÅùëìN=N_{c}N_{f} and assumed to be fixed and large [8]. The aim of this paper is to investigate the trade-off between the two types of processing gain, NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} and NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}, and to calculate the optimal NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} (NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}) value such that bit error probability (BEP) of the system is minimized555footnotetext: The FCC regulations also impose restriction on peak-to-average ratio (PAR), which is not considered in this paper [2].. In other words, the problem is to decide whether or not sending more pulses each with less energy is more desirable in terms of BEP performance than sending fewer pulses each with more energy (Figure 1).

This problem is originally investigated in [8]. Also [9] analyzed the problem from an information theoretic point of view for the single-user case. In [8], it is concluded that in multiuser flat fading channels, the system performance is independent of the pulse combining gain for an IR system with pulse-based polarity randomization and it is in favor of small pulse combining gain for an IR system without pulse-based polarity randomization. However, the analysis is performed in the absence of any timing jitter. Due to the high time resolution of UWB signals, effects of timing jitter are usually not negligible [10]-[12] in IR-UWB systems. As will be observed in this paper, presence of timing jitter has an effect on the trade-off between the processing gains, which can modify the dependency of the BEP expressions on the processing gain parameters. In this paper, the trade-off between the two types of processing gain is investigated in the presence of timing jitter for TH IR systems. First, transmission over an additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel is considered and the trade-off is investigated for IR systems with and without pulse-based polarity randomization. Both symbol-synchronous and chip-synchronous cases are investigated. Also frequency-selective channels are considered and the performance of a downlink IR system with pulse-based polarity randomization is analyzed.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. Section II describes the signal model for an IR system. Section III investigates the trade-off between processing gain parameters for IR systems with and without pulse-based polarity randomization over AWGN channels. In each case, the results for symbol-synchronous and chip-synchronous systems are presented. Section IV considers transmission over frequency-selective channels and adopts a quite general Rake receiver structure at the receiver. After the simulation studies in Section V, some conclusions are made in Section VI.

N=Nc‚ÄãNfùëÅsubscriptùëÅùëêsubscriptùëÅùëìN=N_{c}N_{f} is defined to be the total processing gain of the system. Assuming a large and constant NùëÅN value [8], the aim is to obtain the optimal NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} (NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}) value that minimizes the BEP of the system.

In this study, we consider chip-synchronous and symbol-synchronous situations for the simplicity of the expressions. However, the current study can be extended to asynchronous systems as well [18]. In this paper, we will see that for coded systems, the effect of the MAI is the same whether the users are symbol-synchronous or chip-synchronous. However, for uncoded systems, the average power of the MAI is larger, hence the BEP is higher, when the users are symbol-synchronous.

We assume, without loss of generality, that the delay of the first user, œÑ(1)superscriptùúè1\tau^{(1)}, is zero. III-A Coded Systems

For symbol-synchronous and chip-synchronous coded systems, the following lemma approximates the probability distribution of a(k)superscriptùëéùëòa^{(k)} in (5):

Lemma III.1

As N‚ü∂‚àû‚ü∂ùëÅN\longrightarrow\infty and NfNc‚ü∂c>0‚ü∂subscriptùëÅùëìsubscriptùëÅùëêùëê0\frac{N_{f}}{N_{c}}\longrightarrow c>0, a(k)superscriptùëéùëòa^{(k)} is asymptotically normally distributed as

a(k)‚àºùí©‚Äã(0,Œ≥2(k)‚ÄãNf/Nc),similar-tosuperscriptùëéùëòùí©0subscriptsuperscriptùõæùëò2subscriptùëÅùëìsubscriptùëÅùëê\displaystyle a^{(k)}\sim{\mathcal{N}}(0\,,\,\gamma^{(k)}_{2}N_{f}/N_{c}), (7)

Proof: See Appendix A-A.

From the previous lemma, it is observed that the distribution of the MAI is the same whether there is symbol-synchronization or chip-synchronization among the users, which is due to the use of random polarity codes in each frame.

From (4) and (7), the BEP of the coded IR system conditioned on the timing jitter of user 111 can be approximated as follows:

Pe|œµi(1)‚âàQ‚Äã(E1Nf‚Äã‚àëj=i‚ÄãNf(i+1)‚ÄãNf‚àí1œïw‚Äã(œµj(1))1Nc‚Äã‚àëk=2NuEk‚ÄãŒ≥2(k)+Nf‚ÄãœÉn2),subscriptùëÉconditionalùëísuperscriptsubscriptbold-italic-œµùëñ1ùëÑsubscriptùê∏1subscriptùëÅùëìsuperscriptsubscriptùëóùëñsubscriptùëÅùëìùëñ1subscriptùëÅùëì1subscriptitalic-œïùë§superscriptsubscriptitalic-œµùëó11subscriptùëÅùëêsuperscriptsubscriptùëò2subscriptùëÅùë¢subscriptùê∏ùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùõæùëò2subscriptùëÅùëìsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëõ2\displaystyle P_{e|\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{i}^{(1)}}\approx Q\left(\frac{\sqrt{\frac{E_{1}}{N_{f}}}\sum_{j=iN_{f}}^{(i+1)N_{f}-1}\phi_{w}(\epsilon_{j}^{(1)})}{\sqrt{\frac{1}{N_{c}}\sum_{k=2}^{N_{u}}E_{k}\gamma^{(k)}_{2}+N_{f}\sigma_{n}^{2}}}\right), (8)

For large values of NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}, it follows from the Central Limit Theorem (CLT) that 1Nf‚Äã‚àëj=i‚ÄãNf(i+1)‚ÄãNf‚àí1[œïw‚Äã(œµj(1))‚àíE‚Äã{œïw‚Äã(œµj(1))}]1subscriptùëÅùëìsuperscriptsubscriptùëóùëñsubscriptùëÅùëìùëñ1subscriptùëÅùëì1delimited-[]subscriptitalic-œïùë§superscriptsubscriptitalic-œµùëó1Esubscriptitalic-œïùë§superscriptsubscriptitalic-œµùëó1\frac{1}{\sqrt{N_{f}}}\sum_{j=iN_{f}}^{(i+1)N_{f}-1}[\phi_{w}(\epsilon_{j}^{(1)})-\textrm{E}\{\phi_{w}(\epsilon_{j}^{(1)})\}] is approximately Gaussian. Then, using the relation E‚Äã{Q‚Äã(X)}=Q‚Äã(Œº^1+œÉ^2)EùëÑùëãùëÑ^ùúá1superscript^ùúé2\textrm{E}\{Q(X)\}=Q\left(\frac{\hat{\mu}}{\sqrt{1+\hat{\sigma}^{2}}}\right) for X‚àºùí©‚Äã(Œº^,œÉ^2)similar-toùëãùí©^ùúásuperscript^ùúé2X\sim\mathcal{N}(\hat{\mu},\hat{\sigma}^{2}) [19], the unconditional BEP can be expressed approximately as follows:

Pe‚âàQ‚Äã(E1‚ÄãŒºE1‚ÄãœÉ2Nf+1N‚Äã‚àëk=2NuEk‚ÄãŒ≥2(k)+œÉn2),subscriptùëÉùëíùëÑsubscriptùê∏1ùúásubscriptùê∏1superscriptùúé2subscriptùëÅùëì1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëò2subscriptùëÅùë¢subscriptùê∏ùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùõæùëò2superscriptsubscriptùúéùëõ2\displaystyle P_{e}\approx Q\left(\frac{\sqrt{E_{1}}\mu}{\sqrt{\frac{E_{1}\sigma^{2}}{N_{f}}+\frac{1}{N}\sum_{k=2}^{N_{u}}E_{k}\gamma^{(k)}_{2}+\sigma_{n}^{2}}}\right), (9)

where Œº=E‚Äã{œïw‚Äã(œµj(1))}ùúáEsubscriptitalic-œïùë§superscriptsubscriptitalic-œµùëó1\mu=\textrm{E}\{\phi_{w}(\epsilon_{j}^{(1)})\} and œÉ2=Var‚Äã{œïw‚Äã(œµj(1))}superscriptùúé2Varsubscriptitalic-œïùë§superscriptsubscriptitalic-œµùëó1\sigma^{2}=\textrm{Var}\{\phi_{w}(\epsilon_{j}^{(1)})\}.

From (9), it is observed that the BEP decreases as NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f} increases, if the first term in the denominator is significant. In other words, the BEP gets smaller for larger number of pulses per information symbol. We observe from (9) that the second term in the denominator, which is due to the MAI, depends on NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} and NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f} only through their product N=Nc‚ÄãNfùëÅsubscriptùëÅùëêsubscriptùëÅùëìN=N_{c}N_{f}. Therefore, the MAI has no effect on the trade-off between processing gains for a fixed total processing gain NùëÅN. The only term that depends on how to distribute NùëÅN between NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} and NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f} is the first term in the denominator, which reflects the effect of timing jitter. This effect is mitigated by choosing small NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c}, or large NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}, which means sending more pulses per information bit. Therefore, for a coded system, keeping NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f} large can help reduce the BEP. Also note that in the absence of timing jitter, (9) reduces to Pe‚âàQ‚Äã(E11N‚Äã‚àëk=2NuEk+œÉn2)subscriptùëÉùëíùëÑsubscriptùê∏11ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëò2subscriptùëÅùë¢subscriptùê∏ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëõ2P_{e}\approx Q\left(\frac{\sqrt{E_{1}}}{\sqrt{\frac{1}{N}\sum_{k=2}^{N_{u}}E_{k}+\sigma_{n}^{2}}}\right), in which case there is no effect of processing gain parameters on BEP performance, as stated in [8].

III-B Uncoded Systems

For coded systems, we have observed that the system performance is the same for symbol-synchronous and chip-synchronous scenarios. For an uncoded system, the effect of MAI changes depending on the type of synchronism, as we study in this section.

For the multiuser case, assume that all the interfering users have the same energy Eùê∏E and probability distributions of the jitters are i.i.d. for all of them. Then, the total MAI can be approximated by a zero mean Gaussian random variable for sufficiently large number of users, NusubscriptùëÅùë¢N_{u}, and, after similar manipulations, the BEP can be expressed approximately as

Pe‚âàQ‚Äã(E1‚ÄãŒºE1‚ÄãœÉ2N‚ÄãNc+(Nu‚àí1)‚ÄãE‚Äã(Œ≥2N+Œ≥12Nc2‚àíŒ≥12N‚ÄãNc)+œÉn2),subscriptùëÉùëíùëÑsubscriptùê∏1ùúásubscriptùê∏1superscriptùúé2ùëÅsubscriptùëÅùëêsubscriptùëÅùë¢1ùê∏subscriptùõæ2ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùõæ12superscriptsubscriptùëÅùëê2superscriptsubscriptùõæ12ùëÅsubscriptùëÅùëêsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëõ2\displaystyle P_{e}\approx Q\left(\frac{\sqrt{E_{1}}\mu}{\sqrt{\frac{E_{1}\sigma^{2}}{N}N_{c}+(N_{u}-1)E\left(\frac{\gamma_{2}}{N}+\frac{\gamma_{1}^{2}}{N_{c}^{2}}-\frac{\gamma_{1}^{2}}{NN_{c}}\right)+\sigma_{n}^{2}}}\right), (14)

where the user index kùëòk is dropped from Œ≥1(k)superscriptsubscriptùõæ1ùëò\gamma_{1}^{(k)} and Œ≥2(k)superscriptsubscriptùõæ2ùëò\gamma_{2}^{(k)} since they are i.i.d. among interfering users.

Considering (14), it is seen that for relatively small NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} values, the second term in the denominator, which is the term due to MAI, can become large and cause an increase in the BEP. Similarly, when NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} is large, the first term in the denominator can become significant and the BEP can become high again. Therefore, we expect to have an optimal NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} value for the interference-limited case. Intuitively, for small NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} values, the number of pulses per bit, NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}, is large. Therefore, we have high BEP due to large amount of MAI. As NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} becomes large, the MAI becomes more negligible. However, making NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} very large can again cause an increase in BEP since NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f} becomes small, in which case the effect of timing jitter becomes more significant. The optimal NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} (NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}) value can be approximated by using (14).

Now consider the chip-synchronous case. In this case, the following lemma approximates the distribution of the overall MAI for large number of equal energy interferers:

Lemma III.3

Let N‚ü∂‚àû‚ü∂ùëÅN\longrightarrow\infty and NcNf‚ü∂c>0‚ü∂subscriptùëÅùëêsubscriptùëÅùëìùëê0\frac{N_{c}}{N_{f}}\longrightarrow c>0. Assume that all (Nu‚àí1)subscriptùëÅùë¢1(N_{u}-1) interfering users have the same bit energy Eùê∏E and i.i.d. jitter statistics. Then, the overall MAI, aùëéa in (4), is approximately distributed, for large NusubscriptùëÅùë¢N_{u}, as

a‚àºùí©‚Äã(0,E‚Äã(Nu‚àí1)Nc‚Äã[Œ≥2+(Nf‚àí1)‚Äã[2‚ÄãNc2‚Äã(Nf‚àí1)+1]3‚ÄãN‚ÄãNc2‚ÄãŒ≥12]),similar-toùëéùí©0ùê∏subscriptùëÅùë¢1subscriptùëÅùëêdelimited-[]subscriptùõæ2subscriptùëÅùëì1delimited-[]2superscriptsubscriptùëÅùëê2subscriptùëÅùëì113ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëÅùëê2superscriptsubscriptùõæ12\displaystyle a\sim{\mathcal{N}}\left(0\,,\,\frac{E(N_{u}-1)}{N_{c}}\left[\gamma_{2}+\frac{(N_{f}-1)[2N_{c}^{2}(N_{f}-1)+1]}{3NN_{c}^{2}}\gamma_{1}^{2}\right]\right), (15)

where Œ≥1subscriptùõæ1\gamma_{1} and Œ≥2subscriptùõæ2\gamma_{2} are as in (III.2).

Proof: The proof is omitted due to space limitations. It mainly depends on some central limit arguments.

Comparing the variance in Lemma III.3 with the variance of the MAI term in the uncoded symbol-synchronous case for large number of equal energy interferers with the same jitter statistics, it can be shown that œÉM‚ÄãA‚ÄãI,c‚Äãh‚Äãi‚Äãp2‚â§œÉM‚ÄãA‚ÄãI,s‚Äãy‚Äãm‚Äãb2subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùëÄùê¥ùêºùëê‚Ñéùëñùëùsubscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùëÄùê¥ùêºùë†ùë¶ùëöùëè\sigma^{2}_{MAI,\,chip}\leq\sigma^{2}_{MAI,\,symb} where

œÉM‚ÄãA‚ÄãI,s‚Äãy‚Äãm‚Äãb2subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùëÄùê¥ùêºùë†ùë¶ùëöùëè\displaystyle\sigma^{2}_{MAI,\,symb} =E‚Äã(Nu‚àí1)Nc‚Äã[Œ≥2+Nf‚àí1Nc‚ÄãŒ≥12],absentùê∏subscriptùëÅùë¢1subscriptùëÅùëêdelimited-[]subscriptùõæ2subscriptùëÅùëì1subscriptùëÅùëêsuperscriptsubscriptùõæ12\displaystyle=\frac{E(N_{u}-1)}{N_{c}}\left[\gamma_{2}+\frac{N_{f}-1}{N_{c}}\,\gamma_{1}^{2}\right], (16)
œÉM‚ÄãA‚ÄãI,c‚Äãh‚Äãi‚Äãp2subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùëÄùê¥ùêºùëê‚Ñéùëñùëù\displaystyle\sigma^{2}_{MAI,\,chip} =E‚Äã(Nu‚àí1)Nc‚Äã[Œ≥2+(Nf‚àí1)‚Äã[2‚ÄãNc2‚Äã(Nf‚àí1)+1]3‚ÄãN‚ÄãNc2‚ÄãŒ≥12],absentùê∏subscriptùëÅùë¢1subscriptùëÅùëêdelimited-[]subscriptùõæ2subscriptùëÅùëì1delimited-[]2superscriptsubscriptùëÅùëê2subscriptùëÅùëì113ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëÅùëê2superscriptsubscriptùõæ12\displaystyle=\frac{E(N_{u}-1)}{N_{c}}\left[\gamma_{2}+\frac{(N_{f}-1)[2N_{c}^{2}(N_{f}-1)+1]}{3NN_{c}^{2}}\,\gamma_{1}^{2}\right], (17)

where the equality is satisfied only for Nf=1subscriptùëÅùëì1N_{f}=1.

The reason behind this inequality can be explained as follows: In the uncoded symbol-synchronous case, interference components from a given user to the pulses of the template signal has the same polarity and therefore they add coherently for each user. However, in the chip-synchronous case, interference to some pulses of the template is due to one information bit whereas the interference to the remaining pulses is due to another information bit because there is a misalignment between symbol transmission instants (Figure 2). Since information bits can be ¬±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1 with equal probability, the interference from a given user to individual pulses of the template signal does not always add coherently. Therefore, the average power of the MAI is smaller in the chip-synchronous case. As the limiting case, consider the coded case, where each individual pulse has a random polarity code. In this case, the overall interference from a user, given the information bit of that user, is zero mean due to the polarity codes. Hence, the overall interference from all users has a smaller average power, given by Œ≥2‚ÄãE‚Äã(Nu‚àí1)/Ncsubscriptùõæ2ùê∏subscriptùëÅùë¢1subscriptùëÅùëê\gamma_{2}E(N_{u}-1)/N_{c}, for equal energy interferers with i.i.d jitter statistics.

By Lemma III.3 and the approximation to the distribution of the signal part of the MF output given the information bit in (4) by a Gaussian random variable, we get

Pe‚âàQ‚Äã(E1‚ÄãŒºE1‚ÄãœÉ2N‚ÄãNc+(Nu‚àí1)‚ÄãE‚Äã[Œ≥2N+(N‚àíNc)‚Äã[2‚ÄãNc‚Äã(N‚àíNc)+1]3‚ÄãN2‚ÄãNc3‚ÄãŒ≥12]+œÉn2),subscriptùëÉùëíùëÑsubscriptùê∏1ùúásubscriptùê∏1superscriptùúé2ùëÅsubscriptùëÅùëêsubscriptùëÅùë¢1ùê∏delimited-[]subscriptùõæ2ùëÅùëÅsubscriptùëÅùëêdelimited-[]2subscriptùëÅùëêùëÅsubscriptùëÅùëê13superscriptùëÅ2superscriptsubscriptùëÅùëê3superscriptsubscriptùõæ12superscriptsubscriptùúéùëõ2\displaystyle P_{e}\approx Q\left(\frac{\sqrt{E_{1}}\mu}{\sqrt{\frac{E_{1}\sigma^{2}}{N}N_{c}+(N_{u}-1)E\left[\frac{\gamma_{2}}{N}+\frac{(N-N_{c})[2N_{c}(N-N_{c})+1]}{3N^{2}N_{c}^{3}}\gamma_{1}^{2}\right]+\sigma_{n}^{2}}}\right), (18)

where Œº=E‚Äã{œïw‚Äã(œµj(1))}ùúáEsubscriptitalic-œïùë§superscriptsubscriptitalic-œµùëó1\mu=\textrm{E}\{\phi_{w}(\epsilon_{j}^{(1)})\} and œÉ2=Var‚Äã{œïw‚Äã(œµj(1))}superscriptùúé2Varsubscriptitalic-œïùë§superscriptsubscriptitalic-œµùëó1\sigma^{2}=\textrm{Var}\{\phi_{w}(\epsilon_{j}^{(1)})\}.

Considering (18), we have similar observations as in the symbol-synchronous case. Considering the interference-limited case, for small NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} values, the second term in the denominator, which is the term due to the MAI, becomes dominant and causes a large BEP. When NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} is large, the MAI becomes less significant since probability of overlaps between pulses decreases. However, for very small NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} values, the effect of the timing jitter can become more significant as can be seen from the first term in the denominator and the BEP can increase again. Therefore, in this case, we again expect to see a trade-off between processing gain parameters.

IV Multipath Case

In this section, the effects of the processing gain parameters, NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} and NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}, on the BEP performance of a coded system are investigated in a frequency-selective environment. The following channel model is considered [20], [21]:

h‚Äã(t)=‚àël=0L‚àí1Œ±l‚ÄãŒ¥‚Äã(t‚àíœÑl),‚Ñéùë°superscriptsubscriptùëô0ùêø1subscriptùõºùëôùõøùë°subscriptùúèùëô\displaystyle h(t)=\sum_{l=0}^{L-1}\alpha_{l}\delta(t-\tau_{l}), (19)

where Œ±lsubscriptùõºùëô\alpha_{l} and œÑlsubscriptùúèùëô\tau_{l} are, respectively, the fading coefficient and the delay of the (l+1)ùëô1(l+1)th path. Note that we assume a single cluster without loss of generality of the analysis. In fact, even a multipath channel model with pulse distortions can be incorporated into the analysis as will be explained at the end of the section.

We consider a downlink scenario, where the transmitted symbols are synchronized, and assume œÑ0=0subscriptùúè00\tau_{0}=0 without loss of generality. Moreover, for the simplicity of the analysis, the delay of the last path, œÑL‚àí1subscriptùúèùêø1\tau_{L-1}, is set to an integer multiple of the chip interval TcsubscriptùëáùëêT_{c}; that is, œÑL‚àí1=(M‚àí1)‚ÄãTcsubscriptùúèùêø1ùëÄ1subscriptùëáùëê\tau_{L-1}=(M-1)T_{c} where MùëÄM is an integer. Note that this does not cause a loss in generality since we can always think of a hypothetical path at Tc‚Äã‚åàœÑL‚àí1/Tc‚åâsubscriptùëáùëêsubscriptùúèùêø1subscriptùëáùëêT_{c}\lceil\tau_{L-1}/T_{c}\rceil with a fading coefficient of zero, with ‚åàx‚åâùë•\lceil x\rceil denoting the smallest integer larger than or equal to xùë•x.

From (1) and (19), the received signal can be expressed as follows:

Consider a generic Rake receiver that combines a number of multipath components of the incoming signal. Rake receivers are considered for UWB systems in order to collect sufficient signal energy from incoming multipath components [22]-[27]. For the iùëñith information symbol, the following signal represents the template signal for such a receiver:

Corresponding to different situations, we consider three different statistics for the jitter at the template signal:

Case-1: The jitter is assumed to be i.i.d. for all different finger and frame indices; that is, œµ^j,lsubscript^italic-œµùëóùëô\hat{\epsilon}_{j,l} for (j,l)‚ààùíµ√ó‚Ñíùëóùëôùíµ‚Ñí(j,l)\in\mathcal{Z}\times\mathcal{L} form an i.i.d. sequence, where where ùíµùíµ\mathcal{Z} is the set of integers and ‚Ñí={0,1,‚Ä¶,L‚àí1}‚Ñí01‚Ä¶ùêø1\mathcal{L}=\{0,1,\ldots,L-1\}.

In other words, œµ^j,l1=œµ^j,l2subscript^italic-œµùëósubscriptùëô1subscript^italic-œµùëósubscriptùëô2\hat{\epsilon}_{j,l_{1}}=\hat{\epsilon}_{j,l_{2}} ‚àÄl1,l2for-allsubscriptùëô1subscriptùëô2\forall l_{1},l_{2} and œµ^j,lsubscript^italic-œµùëóùëô\hat{\epsilon}_{j,l} for j‚ààùíµùëóùíµj\in\mathcal{Z} form an i.i.d. sequence.

The IFI is the self interference among the pulses of the user of interest, user 111, which occurs when a pulse in a frame spills over to adjacent frame(s) due to multipath and/or timing jitter and interferes with a pulse in that frame. Lemma IV.2

Since we assume that the timing jitter variables at the transmitted pulses in different frames form an i.i.d. sequence for a given user, and the jitter at the template is i.i.d. among different frames, the first term in (22) given the information bit of user 111 converges to a Gaussian random variable for large NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f} values. Using this observation and the results of the previous two lemmas, we can express the BEP of the system as

where

œÉI‚ÄãF‚ÄãI2=‚àëj=1Mj‚ÄãE‚Äã{[œïu‚Äãv(m)‚Äã(j‚ÄãTc+œµm+1(1))+œïu‚Äãv(m)‚Äã(‚àíj‚ÄãTc+œµm‚àí1(1))]2}superscriptsubscriptùúéùêºùêπùêº2superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÄùëóEsuperscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptitalic-œïùë¢ùë£ùëöùëósubscriptùëáùëêsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œµùëö11superscriptsubscriptitalic-œïùë¢ùë£ùëöùëósubscriptùëáùëêsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œµùëö112\displaystyle\sigma_{IFI}^{2}=\sum_{j=1}^{M}j\,\textrm{E}\{[\phi_{uv}^{(m)}(jT_{c}+\epsilon_{m+1}^{(1)})+\phi_{uv}^{(m)}(-jT_{c}+\epsilon_{m-1}^{(1)})]^{2}\} (30)

and

œÉM‚ÄãA‚ÄãI,k2=‚àëj=‚àíMME‚Äã{[œïu‚Äãv(m)‚Äã(j‚ÄãTc+œµ(k))]2}superscriptsubscriptùúéùëÄùê¥ùêºùëò2superscriptsubscriptùëóùëÄùëÄEsuperscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptitalic-œïùë¢ùë£ùëöùëósubscriptùëáùëêsuperscriptitalic-œµùëò2\displaystyle\sigma_{MAI,k}^{2}=\sum_{j=-M}^{M}\textrm{E}\{[\phi_{uv}^{(m)}(jT_{c}+\epsilon^{(k)})]^{2}\} (31)

are independent of the processing gain parameters.

From (29), a trade-off between the effect of the timing jitter and that of the IFI is observed. The first term in the denominator, which is due to the effect of the timing jitter on the desired signal part of the output in (22), can cause an increase in the BEP as NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} increases. The second term in the denominator is due to the IFI, which can cause a decrease in the BEP as NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} increases; because, as NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} increases, the probability of a spill-over from one frame to the next decreases. Hence, large NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} values mitigate the effects of IFI. The term due to the MAI (the third term in the denominator) does not depend on NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} (NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}) for a given value of total processing gain NùëÅN. Therefore, it has no effect on the trade-off between processing gains. The optimal value of NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} (NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}) minimizes the BEP by optimally mitigating the opposing effects of the timing jitter and the IFI.

Remark-1: The same conclusions hold for Case-3, in which the timing jitter at the template signal is the same for all frames for a given finger, and i.i.d. among different fingers. In this case, conditioning on the jitter values at different fingers (œµ^j,0‚Äã‚ãØ‚Äãœµ^j,L‚àí1subscript^italic-œµùëó0‚ãØsubscript^italic-œµùëóùêø1\hat{\epsilon}_{j,0}\cdots\hat{\epsilon}_{j,L-1}), the conditional BEP (Pe|œµ^j,0‚Äã‚ãØ‚Äãœµ^j,L‚àí1conditionalsubscriptùëÉesubscript^italic-œµùëó0‚ãØsubscript^italic-œµùëóùêø1P_{{\rm{e}}}|\hat{\epsilon}_{j,0}\cdots\hat{\epsilon}_{j,L-1}) can be shown to be as in (29); hence, the same dependence structure on the processing gain parameters is observed. The only difference in this case is that the statistical averages are calculated only over the jitter values at the transmitter.

Remark-2: For the case in which pulses are also distorted by the channel; i.e., pulse shapes in different multipath components are different, the analysis is still valid. V Simulation Results

In this section, BEP performances of coded and uncoded IR systems are simulated for different values of processing gains, and the results are compared with the theoretical analysis. The UWB pulse999footnotetext: wrx‚Äã(t)=w‚Äã(t)/Epsubscriptùë§rxùë°ùë§ùë°subscriptùê∏ùëùw_{{\rm{rx}}}(t)=w(t)/\sqrt{E_{p}} with Ep=‚à´‚àí‚àû‚àûw2‚Äã(t)‚Äãùëëtsubscriptùê∏ùëùsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùë§2ùë°differential-dùë°E_{p}=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}w^{2}(t)dt is used as the received UWB pulse with unit energy. and the normalized autocorrelation function used in the simulations are as follows [29]:

where œÑ=0.125‚Äãnsùúè0.125ns\tau=0.125\,\rm{ns} is used (Figure 3).

For the first set of simulations, the timing jitter at the transmitter is modelled by ùí∞‚Äã[‚àí25‚Äãps,25‚Äãps]ùí∞25ps25ps\mathcal{U}[-25\,{\rm{ps}},25\,{\rm{ps}}], where ùí∞‚Äã[x,y]ùí∞ùë•ùë¶\mathcal{U}[x,y] denotes the uniform distribution on [x,y]ùë•ùë¶[x,y] [10], [17], and TcsubscriptùëáùëêT_{c} is chosen to be 0.25‚Äãns0.25ns0.25\,{\rm{ns}}. The total processing gain N=Nc‚ÄãNfùëÅsubscriptùëÅùëêsubscriptùëÅùëìN=N_{c}N_{f} is taken to be 512512512. Also all 101010 users (Nu=10subscriptùëÅùë¢10N_{u}=10) are assumed to be sending unit-energy bits (Ek=1subscriptùê∏ùëò1E_{k}=1 ‚àÄkfor-allùëò\forall k) and œÉn2=0.1superscriptsubscriptùúéùëõ20.1\sigma_{n}^{2}=0.1.

Figure 4 shows the BEP of the coded and the uncoded IR-UWB systems for different NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f} values in an AWGN environment. It is observed that the simulation results match quite closely with the theoretical values. For the coded system, the BEP decreases as NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f} increases. Since the effect of the MAI on the BEP is asymptotically independent of NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}, the only effect to consider is that of the timing jitter. Since the effect of the timing jitter is reduced for large NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}, the plots for the coded system show a decrease in BEP as NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f} increases. As expected, the performance is the same for the symbol-synchronous and chip-synchronous coded systems. For the uncoded system, there is an optimal value of the processing gain that minimizes the BEP of the system. In this case, there are both the effects of the timing jitter and the MAI. The effect of the timing jitter is mitigated using large NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}, while that of the MAI is reduced using small NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}. The optimal value of the processing gains can be approximately calculated using (14) or (18). As expected, the effect of the MAI is larger for the symbol-synchronous system, which causes a larger BEP for such systems compared to the chip-synchronous ones.

In Figure 5, the BEPs of the coded and uncoded systems are plotted for different signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs). As observed from the figure, as the SNR increases, the trade-off between the processing gains become more significant. This is because, for large SNR, the background noise gets small compared to the noise due to jitter or MAI; hence, the change of processing gain parameters causes significant changes in the BEP of the system due to the effects of timing jitter (and MAI in the uncoded case).

In Figure 6, the effects of jitter distribution on the system performance are investigated. The BEPs of the coded and uncoded systems are plotted for zero mean uniform [17] and Gaussian [16] timing jitters with the same variance (208.3208.3208.3 ps2). From the figure, it is observed that the Gaussian timing jitter increases the BEP more than the uniform timing jitter; i.e. as the timing jitter becomes significant (for small NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}), the BEP of the system with Gaussian jitter gets larger than that of the system with uniform jitter. The main reason for this difference is that the Gaussian jitter can take significantly large values corresponding to the tail of the distribution, which considerably affects the average BEP of the system.

Now consider a multipath channel with L=10ùêø10L=10 paths, where the fading coefficients are given by [0.4653‚Äâ‚Äâ‚Äâ‚Äâ0.5817‚Äâ‚Äâ‚Äâ‚Äâ0.2327‚àí0.4536‚Äâ‚Äâ‚Äâ‚Äâ0.3490‚Äâ‚Äâ‚Äâ‚Äâ0.2217‚àí0.1163‚Äâ‚Äâ‚Äâ‚Äâ0.0233‚àí0.0116‚àí0.0023]delimited-[]0.46530.58170.23270.45360.34900.22170.11630.02330.01160.0023[0.4653\,\,\,\,0.5817\,\,\,\,0.2327-0.4536\,\,\,\,0.3490\,\,\,\,0.2217-0.1163\,\,\,\,0.0233-0.0116-0.0023], and the delays by œÑl=l‚ÄãTcsubscriptùúèùëôùëôsubscriptùëáùëê\tau_{l}=lT_{c} for l=0,‚Ä¶,L‚àí1ùëô0‚Ä¶ùêø1l=0,\ldots,L-1, where Tc=0.25subscriptùëáùëê0.25T_{c}=0.25\,ns. The Rake receiver combines all the multipath components using maximal ratio combining (MRC). The jitter is modelled as ùí∞‚Äã[‚àí20‚Äãps,20‚Äãps]ùí∞20ps20ps\mathcal{U}[-20\,{\rm{ps}},20\,{\rm{ps}}], the total processing gain NùëÅN is equal to 512512512, and œÉn2=0.01superscriptsubscriptùúéùëõ20.01\sigma_{n}^{2}=0.01. There are 101010 users in the system where the first user transmits bits with unit energy (E1=1subscriptùê∏11E_{1}=1), while the others have Ek=E=5subscriptùê∏ùëòùê∏5E_{k}=E=5 ‚àÄkfor-allùëò\forall k.

Figure 7 plots the BEP of a coded IR-UWB system for a downlink scenario, in which user 111 is considered as the user of interest and the jitter at the template is as described in Case-1 and Case-2 in Section IV. Note that the theoretical and simulation results get closer as the number of pulses per symbol, NfsubscriptùëÅfN_{{\rm{f}}}, increases, as the Gaussian approximation becomes more and more accurate. It is observed that the BEP decreases as NfsubscriptùëÅfN_{{\rm{f}}} increases since the effect of timing jitter is reduced. However, the effect of IFI is not observed since it is negligible compared to the other noise sources. Hence, no significant increase in BEP is observed for larger NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}, although the IFI increases. Finally, it is observed that the BEPs for Case-1 are smaller than those for Case-2. In other words, the effects of timing jitter are smaller when the jitter is i.i.d. among all the frames and fingers than when it is the same for all the fingers in a given frame and i.i.d. among different frames.

VI Conclusion

The trade-off between the processing gains of an IR system has been investigated in the presence of timing jitter. It has been concluded that, in an AWGN channel, sending more pulses per bit decreases the BEP of a coded system since the effect of the MAI on the BEP is independent of processing gains for a given total processing gain, and the effect of the i.i.d. timing jitter is reduced by sending more pulses. The system performs the same whether the users are symbol-synchronous or chip-synchronous. In an uncoded system, there is a trade-off between NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c} and NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}, which reflects the effects of the timing jitter and the MAI. Optimal processing gains can be found by using the approximate closed form expressions for the BEP. It is also concluded that the effect of the MAI is mitigated when the users are chip-synchronous. Therefore, the BEP of a chip-synchronous uncoded system is smaller than that of a symbol-synchronous uncoded system.

For frequency-selective environments, the MAI has no effect on the trade-off between the processing gains of a symbol-synchronous coded system. However, the IFI is mitigated for larger values of NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c}, hence affects the trade-off between the processing gains. Again the effect of the timing jitter is mitigated by increasing NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f}. Therefore, there is a trade-off between the effects of the timing jitter and that of the IFI and the optimal NfsubscriptùëÅùëìN_{f} (NcsubscriptùëÅùëêN_{c}) value can be chosen by using the approximate BEP expression.

Related to the trade-off study in this paper, investigation of the trade-off between processing gain parameters of a transmitted reference (TR) UWB system [30], [31] remains as an open research problem. Due to the autocorrelation receiver employed in TR UWB systems, the investigation of receiver output statistics would be more challenging in that case.

Sinan Gezici received the B.S. degree from Bilkent University, Turkey in 2001, and the Ph.D. degree in Electrical Engineering from Princeton University in 2006. From April 2006 to January 2007, he worked as a Visiting Member of Technical Staff at Mitsubishi Electric Research Laboratories, Cambridge, MA. Since February 2007, he has been an Assistant Professor in the Department of Electrical and Electronics Engineering at Bilkent University.

Dr. Gezici‚Äôs research interests are in the areas of signal detection, estimation and optimization theory, and their applications to wireless communications and localization systems. Currently, he has a particular interest in ultra-wideband systems for communications and sensing applications.

Andreas F. Molisch (S‚Äô89, M‚Äô95, SM‚Äô00, F‚Äô05) received the Dipl. Ing., Dr. techn., and habilitation degrees from the Technical University Vienna (Austria) in 1990, 1994, and 1999, respectively. From 1991 to 2000, he was with the TU Vienna, becoming an associate professor there in 1999. From 2000-2002, he was with the Wireless Systems Research Department at AT&T (Bell) Laboratories Research in Middletown, NJ. Since then, he has been with Mitsubishi Electric Research Labs, Cambridge, MA, where he is now a Distinguished Member of Technical Staff. He is also professor and chairholder for radio systems at Lund University, Sweden.

Dr. Molisch has done research in the areas of SAW filters, radiative transfer in atomic vapors, atomic line filters, smart antennas, and wideband systems. His current research interests are measurement and modeling of mobile radio channels, UWB, cooperative communications, and MIMO systems. Dr. Molisch has authored, co-authored or edited four books (among them the recent textbook ‚ÄúWireless Communications,‚Äù Wiley-IEEE Press), eleven book chapters, some 95 journal papers, and numerous conference contributions.

Dr. Molisch is an editor of the IEEE Trans. Wireless Comm., co-editor of recent special issues on MIMO and smart antennas (in J. Wireless Comm. Mob. Comp.), and UWB (in IEEE - JSAC). He has been member of numerous TPCs, vice chair of the TPC of VTC 2005 spring, general chair of ICUWB 2006, and TPC co-chair of the wireless symposium of Globecomm 2007. He has participated in the European research initiatives ‚ÄúCOST 231‚Äù, ‚ÄúCOST 259‚Äù, and ‚ÄúCOST273‚Äù, where he was chairman of the MIMO channel working group, he was chairman of the IEEE 802.15.4a channel model standardization group, and is also chairman of Commission C (signals and systems) of URSI (International Union of Radio Scientists). Dr. Molisch is a Fellow of the IEEE and recipient of several awards.

H. Vincent Poor (S‚Äô72, M‚Äô77, SM‚Äô82, F‚Äô77) received the Ph.D. degree in EECS from Princeton University in 1977. Dr. Poor‚Äôs research interests are in the areas of stochastic analysis, statistical signal processing and their applications in wireless networks and related fields. Recent recognition of his work includes a Guggenheim Fellowship and the IEEE Education Medal.

Hisashi Kobayashi is the Sherman Fairchild University Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at Princeton University since 1986, when he joined the Princeton faculty as the Dean of the School of Engineering and Applied Science (1986-91). From 1967 till 1982 he was with the IBM Research Center in Yorktown Heights, and from 1982 to 1986 he served as the founding Director of the IBM Tokyo Research Laboratory. His research experiences include radar systems, high speed data transmission, coding for high density digital recording, image compression algorithms, performance modeling and analysis of computers and communication systems. His current research activities are on performance modeling and analysis of high speed networks, wireless communications and geolocation algorithms, network security, and teletraffic & queuing theory. He published ‚ÄúModeling and Analysis‚Äù (Addison-Wesley, 1978), and is authoring a new book with B. L.
